author: Robert O'Brien
title: Web-of-Trust Digital Identity

assessments.note:
In the long run SSID is critical for fair financial / economic inclusion of all the world's peoples. The challenge is well thought out. Consider including a couple of more examples around the world (not only Maori/NZ) - maybe even one per continent - to make it truly a global challenge.

It's good that it is focused and, maybe later, it can be extended to include "paperless people" (the unbanked) mentioned in the comments.

Great idea and implementation of the Atala PRISM technology.
Why not take it further and offer a general challenge for all communities instead of just indigenous?

I'ts an interesting idea, but why not everybody, indigenous aside we are all in the need of similar applications. The challenge is critical for the integration of the world community and with that indigenous as well to onboard all possible identities into the new ways of interfacing future blockchain applications and technologies.

As much as I support the basic idea, I suggest to join forces with the 'Nation Building' initiative within this campaign. If we focus on outlining and drafting systems for emerging country governments and indigenous or similar communities, we can be more successful. I do think that the USD 400.000 estimate is very high, since it would consume all the funding of this campaign. Therefore my No. Please join forces and partner up.
A detail of the requested funding would help to understand the amount asked better. It is in my opinion that if you broaden the challenge, it justifies the amount better towards the voters.

The community has the ability to start a progress toward doing this once smart contracts launch in the network, some of the critical questions are how to authenticate an individual and how can it be recognize by the legacy system as a true method of identity. Indigenous communities could be a great start from smaller groups up to mass adoption across the world.

Even though this is a well-elaborated input, there are a lot of interdependences and network-building required for making this fly. Therefore again: Let's lift this topic to a more generic level and partner up with the 'Nation Building' idea.

I don't see much of the metrics here. Also would be nice to know what exactly will that 400,000 USD be used for.

Perhaps the funding could be divided, 'cos this is clearly a two-part challenge:
1. How might we enable indigenous communities to benefit from Digital Identity?
2. What kind of solutions can we build for members of indigenous communities who have a digital identity?

Clear metrics are set.
A roadmap to help guide projects based on this proposed challenge would stimulate productiveness.

The solution for a start seams like a well established point of integration with a group, a database and the intention of bringing the opportunities opening up in the Horizon with smart contract. Is a good start!
very high price tag for this so needs be broken down it to very definitive deliverables backed by a scope and budgeted into "man hours" per deliverable
Quite unclear to me, how this is intended to be approached. Is this partnering up with ATALA Prism ? Again: I strongly suggest to join forces with the 'Nation Building' idea.

importance: Indigenous communities struggle to retain their culture. Digital Identity can strengthen collective identity and economic wellbeing.
success: Community members have the tools needed to educate, help and onboard others in their community to set up digital identities easily.
